industry: Industrial Machinery Manufacturing and Automation Machinery Manufacturing
description:
ABOUT THE ROLE:

The Manufacturing Supervisor is the leader for the Systems Department production floor.


The Manufacturing Supervisor is responsible for managing the Benchmark, Laser System, and Machine Shop production. The Systems Manufacturing Supervisor has a proven background in leadership with an understanding of manufacturing processes required to support an automation technology and production assembly, technician, and machinist team. This position's duties and responsibilities may involve the performance of manual work.


RESPONSIBILITIES:

  • Work in and foster a team environment with engineers, production assemblers and technicians, QA technicians, planning, contract management, machinists, and sales personnel.
  • Train and supervise a team of electro-mechanical assemblers and technicians.
  • Prepare detailed manufacturing schedules for the Systems group backlog based on coordination with Systems Engineering Manager.
  • Approve, create, and provide guidance for manufacturing procedures with Systems Engineering support.
  • Managing: Supervises, organizes, and monitors the Laser Systems, Benchmark, and Model Shop assembly and machinist teams to produce Systems projects and Standard Products on or ahead of schedules and of high quality.
  • Creates clear expectations for Systems Manufacturing employees based on experience and roles.
  • Set performance goals and provide regular feedback via informal and scheduled reviews.
  • Manage department to achieve sales order cost and schedule goals.
  • Recruit, hire, and organize training for new assemblers and machinists.
  • Develop and report on production floor metrics.
  • Resolve personnel problems with HR by analyzing, investigating, and providing solutions.
  • Work with Facilities group to develop and maintain safety and cleanliness standards for a production floor producing custom automation systems.
  • You will supervise ten to fifteen direct reports.
